Question: 7 (i)
Scheme:
For setting up the contradiction: \\
There exists integers \(p\) and \(q\) such that \(p q\) is even and both \(p\) and \\
\(q\) are odd

For example, sets \(p=2 m+1\) and \(q=2 n+1\) and then attempts \\
\(p q=(2 m+1)(2 n+1)=\ldots\)

Obtains \(p q=(2 m+1)(2 n+1)=4 m n+2 m+2 n+1\) \\
\(=2(2 m n+m+n)+1\) \\
States that this is odd, giving a contradiction so \\
" if \(p q\) is even, then at least one of \(p\) and \(q\) is even" *

States that as \\
\(x<0  \Rightarrow 2 y>8 x \\
 \Rightarrow y>4 x *\)

Question: 14(a)
Scheme:
Attempts to use both \\

\(\sin \left(x-60^{\circ}\right)= \pm \sin x \cos 60^{\circ} \pm \cos x \sin 60^{\circ}\) \\
\(\cos \left(x-30^{\circ}\right)= \pm \cos x \cos 30^{\circ} \pm \sin x \sin 30^{\circ}\)

Correct equation \\
\(2 \sin x \cos 60^{\circ}-2 \cos x \sin 60^{\circ}=\cos x \cos 30^{\circ}+\sin x \sin 30^{\circ}\)

Either uses \(\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}=\tan x\) and attempts to make \(\tan x\) the subject \\
E.g. \(\left(2 \cos 60^{\circ}-\sin 30^{\circ}\right) \tan x=\cos 30^{\circ}+2 \sin 60^{\circ}\) \\
Or attempts \(\sin 30^{\circ}\) etc with at least two correct and collects terms in \\
\(\sin x\) and \(\cos x\) \\
E.g. \(\left(2 \times \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\right) \sin x=\left(2 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) \cos x\)

Proceeds to given answer showing all key steps \\
E.g. \(\frac{1}{2} \tan x=\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} \Rightarrow \tan x=3 \sqrt{3}\)
Correct method to find one value of \(\theta\) E.g \(\theta=\frac{79.1^{\circ}-60^{\circ}}{2}\)
